fields.name: Homepage introduction
fields.content:
The White House and New York University’s Information Law Institute, with support from Google Open Research, Microsoft Research and the MacArthur Foundation will host a major public conference to address the near-term impacts of AI technologies across social and economic systems.

The focus will be the challenges of the next 5-10 years, specifically addressing four themes: social inequality, labor, healthcare, and ethics. Leaders from industry, academia, and civil society will share ideas for technical design, research and policy directions.
fields._content_rendered:
The White House and New York University’s Information Law Institute, with support from Google Open Research, Microsoft Research and the MacArthur Foundation will host a major public conference to address the near-term impacts of AI technologies across social and economic systems.

The focus will be the challenges of the next 5-10 years, specifically addressing four themes: social inequality, labor, healthcare, and ethics. Leaders from industry, academia, and civil society will share ideas for technical design, research and policy directions.

fields.name: Homepage tickets
fields.content:
Admission is free, but tickets will be required.

As of June 20th tickets for this event are sold out. Please check back soon for more information.
fields._content_rendered:
Admission is free, but tickets will be required.

As of June 20th tickets for this event are sold out. Please check back soon for more information.

fields.name: Workshop venue introduction
fields.content: We’ll be meeting at the Grand Hall of New York University’s Kimmel Center. Use the dedicated entrance at 238 Thompson Street. Please bring ID.
fields._content_rendered: We’ll be meeting at the Grand Hall of New York University’s Kimmel Center. Use the dedicated entrance at 238 Thompson Street. Please bring ID.

fields.name: Workshop introduction
fields.content:
We are delighted to invite you to a workshop of leaders and thinkers for “AI Now: The Social and Economic Implications of Artificial Intelligence Technologies in the Near-Term”.  Experts and researchers from across industry, civil society, academia and the White House will gather for a frank and productive day of discussion focusing on the challenges posed by artificial intelligence technologies in the next 5-10 years.

Conversation will focus specifically on four key themes: social inequality, ethics, labor, and healthcare.

The event aims to amplify the voices of those with significant insight and experience across the four areas, with the goal of building new bridges across different communities. Together, we will consider the potential benefits and challenges of AI technologies, and analyze how to ensure AI is built for equality of opportunity.

Following the workshop, attendees will be invited as honored guests to a major public symposium addressing these topics, co-hosted by The White House and New York University’s Information Law Institute, with the support of the MacArthur Foundation.

We think your work is important to this emerging set of debates, and we want to add your voice and perspective. Explore further details on the site, and send along any questions you might have.
fields._content_rendered:
We are delighted to invite you to a workshop of leaders and thinkers for “AI Now: The Social and Economic Implications of Artificial Intelligence Technologies in the Near-Term”. Experts and researchers from across industry, civil society, academia and the White House will gather for a frank and productive day of discussion focusing on the challenges posed by artificial intelligence technologies in the next 5-10 years.

Conversation will focus specifically on four key themes: social inequality, ethics, labor, and healthcare.

The event aims to amplify the voices of those with significant insight and experience across the four areas, with the goal of building new bridges across different communities. Together, we will consider the potential benefits and challenges of AI technologies, and analyze how to ensure AI is built for equality of opportunity.

Following the workshop, attendees will be invited as honored guests to a major public symposium addressing these topics, co-hosted by The White House and New York University’s Information Law Institute, with the support of the MacArthur Foundation.

We think your work is important to this emerging set of debates, and we want to add your voice and perspective. Explore further details on the site, and send along any questions you might have.

fields.content: Schedule subject to change.  We'll confirm the schedule closer to the day of the workshop.
fields._content_rendered: Schedule subject to change. We'll confirm the schedule closer to the day of the workshop.

fields.name: Conference sidebar
fields.content: Schedule subject to change.  We'll confirm the schedule closer to the day of the conference. The event will be live-streamed.

fields.name: Harassment policy
fields.content:
AI Now is dedicated to providing a safer experience for all attendees, regardless of gender, gender identity and expression, sexual orientation, disability, physical appearance, body size, race, or religion. We do not tolerate harassment of conference participants in any form. Participants violating these rules may be sanctioned or expelled from the symposium at the discretion of the organizers.

* Harassment includes offensive verbal comments, related to gender, gender identity and expression, sexual orientation, disability, physical appearance, body size, race, religion, deliberate intimidation, stalking, following, harassing photography or recording, sustained disruption of talks or other events, inappropriate physical contact, and unwelcome sexual attention.
* Participants asked to stop any harassing behaviour are expected to comply immediately. All venue staff, event organizers and volunteers are also subject to the anti-harassment policy.
* If a participant engages in harassing behaviour, the organizers may take any action they deem appropriate, including warning the offender or expulsion from the symposium.
* If you are being harassed, notice that someone else is being harassed, or have any other concerns, please contact a member of conference staff immediately by coming to the information booth at registration or one of our volunteers who will be throughout the venue.

Symposium staff / volunteers will be happy to help participants contact venue security or local law enforcement, provide escorts, or otherwise assist those experiencing harassment to feel safer for the duration of the conference.

We value your attendance and appreciate your cooperation with this policy.

We expect participants to follow these rules at all AI Now-related sessions and social events.

(Adapted from [http://geekfeminism.wikia.com/wiki/Conference_anti-harassment/Policy](http://geekfeminism.wikia.com/wiki/Conference_anti-harassment/Policy))

We do not tolerate harassment of conference participants in any form. Participants violating these rules may be sanctioned or expelled from the symposium at the discretion of the organizers.

  • Harassment includes offensive verbal comments, related to gender, gender identity and expression, sexual orientation, disability, physical appearance, body size, race, religion, deliberate intimidation, stalking, following, harassing photography or recording, sustained disruption of talks or other events, inappropriate physical contact, and unwelcome sexual attention.
  • Participants asked to stop any harassing behaviour are expected to comply immediately. All venue staff, event organizers and volunteers are also subject to the anti-harassment policy.
  • If a participant engages in harassing behaviour, the organizers may take any action they deem appropriate, including warning the offender or expulsion from the symposium.
  • If you are being harassed, notice that someone else is being harassed, or have any other concerns, please contact a member of conference staff immediately by coming to the information booth at registration or one of our volunteers who will be throughout the venue.

Symposium staff / volunteers will be happy to help participants contact venue security or local law enforcement, provide escorts, or otherwise assist those experiencing harassment to feel safer for the duration of the conference.

We value your attendance and appreciate your cooperation with this policy.

We expect participants to follow these rules at all AI Now-related sessions and social events.

(Adapted from http://geekfeminism.wikia.com/wiki/Conference_anti-harassment/Policy)

fields.name: Chatham House Rule
fields.content:
While attending the AI Now Workshop, we ask that you follow the Chatham House Rule, which states:

> “When a meeting, or part thereof, is held under the Chatham House Rule, participants are free to use the information received, but neither the identity nor the affiliation of the speaker(s), nor that of any other participant, may be revealed.”
fields._content_rendered:
While attending the AI Now Workshop, we ask that you follow the Chatham House Rule, which states:

“When a meeting, or part thereof, is held under the Chatham House Rule, participants are free to use the information received, but neither the identity nor the affiliation of the speaker(s), nor that of any other participant, may be revealed.”
